cardiovascular effect: In a rabbit study, 10mg/kg of total saponins significantly reduced blood cholesterol and blood pressure, lowered heart rate, increased heart contraction amplitude, increased urine output, reduced the β/α ratio of lipoprotein and improved coronary circulation. It was suggested it may be effective for patients with mild atherosclerosis (animal study).
anti-cancer effect: inhibited the invasion of oral cancer cells and may have potential use as a chemopreventive agent against oral cancer metastasis.[1]
inhibitory potential against fat absorption thus may have anti obesity effect. [4]
anti-inflammatory effect [6]
Dosage: Oral: make into decoction, 15 to 30 g (fresh herb, double the amount), or soak in rice wine. External application: smash and apply.
Samples of Formulae: For sore loin and legs, numbness in muscle: Prescription: fresh chuan shan long roots and rhizoma 60 g, some brown sugar. Simmer with a pot of water. Use as tea. It can be reboiled 5 or 6 times. [5]
Contraindications: Injection experiments done on mice resulted in an LD50 of 9.9 g crude drug/kg for the first group, and 19 g crude drug/kg for the second group. Oral saponins had an LD50 of 2.21±0.14 g/kg in mice.
Research: Cardiovascular effect observed in rabbits: total saponins at 10mg/kg significantly reduced blood cholesterol and blood pressure, lowered heart rate, increased heart contraction amplitude, increased urine output, reduced β/α ratio of lipoprotein, and improved coronary circulation, suggesting potential efficacy for mild atherosclerosis.[1] Anti-cancer research showed inhibition of oral cancer cell invasion; thus, potentially useful as a chemopreventive agent against oral cancer metastasis [1]. Studies showed inhibitory potential against fat absorption suggesting potential anti-obesity effects [4]. Confirmed anti-inflammatory effects observed [6].

Name: lu feng fang
露蜂房
Other: da huang chan chao 大黃 蟾巢

Maladies Treated: lung cancer: symptoms such as phlegm cough and chest pain
stomach cancer: stomach distention and pain, tumor mass
tongue cancer: difficulty swallowing and breathing, tumor masses
gum cancer: chewing discomfort, pain, and bleeding, tumor mass
esophageal cancer: symptoms of acid reflux and spitting, difficulty swallowing, tumor mass
liver cancer: abdominal distension and pain, enlargement of the liver and spleen, tumor mass extending survival period
breast cancer: pain and tumor masses, skin lesions
cervical cancer: vaginal leucorrhea discharge and bleeding, cervical lesions upon examination
skin diseases such as eczema, wind sores, itching rash, scrofulous sores, carbuncles, abscess, stubborn skin ulcers, lupus-like conditions
tumors and bleeding: navel dampness swelling, tongue swelling with bleeding, nasal polyp (nasal hemorrhoids) bleeding, nasal bleeding
Medical Function: in vitro studies showed it inhibits human liver cancer cells, effective against stomach cancer cells in methylene blue staining method (in-vitro)
alcohol, ether or ketone extracts promote blood coagulation
all extracts strengthen heart activity, temporarily lower blood pressure, and possess diuretic effect
oil of lu feng fang (volatile oil) can expel tapeworms, but due to strong toxicity, it is not suitable for this use
high concentration of lu feng fang oil inhibits isolated frog hearts in vitro, strongly stimulates kidneys, causing acute nephritis
Dosage: In decoction: 6 to 15 g. For pills and powders: 0.3 to 9 g. External use: appropriate amount.
Samples of Formulae:
For lung cancer, use 15g of Lu Feng Fang (Hornet Nest), 1.5g each of Jie Geng (Platycodon), Chen Pi (Aged Tangerine Peel), and Sheng Gan Cao (Raw Licorice), 9g each of Zhe Bei Mu, Ban Xia (Pinellia), Ju Ye (Tangerine Leaf), and Dang Shen (Codonopsis), and 30g of Yi Yi Ren (Coix seed), chopped and decocted in water. One dose per day can relieve symptoms such as coughing phlegm and chest pain, and gradually reduce tumor mass. 
 For stomach cancer, use 6g each of roasted Lu Feng Fang, roasted Qiang Lang (Dung beetle), and calcined Zhe Shi (Hematite), with 3g each of roasted Quan Xie (Scorpion), Chen Pi, and Gan Cao, ground into fine powder and divided into 10 packets. Take one packet twice daily with warm water. This treatment alleviates bloating and pain, and reduces tumor mass. 
 For tongue cancer, use 9g each of Lu Feng Fang, She Tui (Snake slough), and Quan Xie, ground and divided into three doses, taken with warm water. This improves swallowing and breathing, and softens the mass.
 For gingival cancer, use 12g Lu Feng Fang, 3g Xi Xin (Asarum), and 30g each of Qi Ye Yi Zhi Hua and Ban Zhi Lian (Barbed Skullcap), decocted and taken in three divided doses daily. It alleviates chewing pain, bleeding, and swelling. 
 For esophageal cancer, use 15g each of Lu Feng Fang, Fan Lou Pi, Xuan Shen, and Zou Ma Tai, 1.5g Bai Fan (Alum), 3g Da Huang (Rhubarb), 4.5g Hong Hua (Safflower), 6g Ma Bo, 9g each of Lian Qiao, Tao Ren, and Zhe Bei Mu, 12g each of Mai Dong (Ophiopogon) and Chi Shao (Red Peony Root), and 30g Mao Mei (Rubus), chopped and decocted in water. One dose per day relieves acid reflux and salivation, reduces mass, and improves swallowing. 
 For liver cancer, use 9g each of Lu Feng Fang, Dang Gui, and Ma Bo, 3g of roasted and powdered Bi Hu (Gecko), 12g each of San Leng (Sparganium) and Tu Bie Chong (Wingless Cockroach), 15g each of Chuan Lian Zi (Sichuan Melia) and Ju He (Tangerine seed), 30g each of Ze Xie, Long Dan Cao, Dong Gua Ren, and Zou Ma Tai, 60g Mian Yin Chen, and 90g Mao Mei, with 10 Wu Gong (Centipedes), roughly ground and decocted in water, divided into three doses daily. This alleviates distension and pain, reduces hepatosplenomegaly, and prolongs survival. 
 For breast cancer, use 9g each of Lu Feng Fang, Tian Hua Fen (Trichosanthes), Kun Bu (Kelp), and Hai Zao (Seaweed), decocted in water and taken in two doses daily. It relieves pain and restores skin appearance. 
 For cervical cancer, use 9g each of Lu Feng Fang and Quan Xie, 6g each of Shui Zhi (Leech), Meng Chong (Tabanus), Zhi Ru Xiang (Prepared Frankincense), Zhi Mo Yao (Prepared Myrrh), Huang Lian, and Huang Bai, 12g Mu Dan Pi, and 15g Long Dan Cao, ground together. Boil 3g Jin Yin Hua (Honeysuckle) to make a decoction, which is used to form pills the size of mung beans, coated with realgar. Each dose is 1.5g, taken twice daily with warm water. For local application, use a cervical powder made from: 1.2g She Xiang (Musk), 4.2g She Chuang Zi, 7.5g Xue Jie (Dragon’s Blood), 9g Mo Yao (Myrrh), and 10.5g each of Ru Xiang (Frankincense), Er Cha (Catechu), Bing Pian (Borneol), Peng Sha (Borax), and Nao Sha (Ammonium Chloride), 13.2g each of Zhong Ru Shi and Xiong Huang (Realgar), 46.5g Qian Dan (Lead Tetroxide), and 285g Bai Fan (Alum), all ground into powder and applied to the cervix twice a week. This combination of internal and topical treatments over six months led to reduced vaginal discharge and bleeding. Upon gynecological reevaluation, lesions disappeared and cervical tissue appeared normal. 
 Dermal Wind Ulcers (Feng Chuang): For general skin wind lesions, use 6g each of Lu Feng Fang, Chan Tui (Cicada Slough), and Fu Ping (Duckweed), with 15g Ye Ju Hua (Wild Chrysanthemum), decocted in water. For rubella, itching, scrofula, and ulcerated wind sores, use 6g each of roasted Lu Feng Fang, Qiang Lang (Dung Beetle), Chan Tui, roasted Jiang Can (Silkworm), Shan Jia Zhu (Pangolin scales), Quan Xie, and Wu Gong (Centipede), 0.6g She Xiang (Musk), and 18g Wu Bei Zi (Chinese gall), all ground together. Take 3g per dose, twice daily with warm water. This also treats abscesses, scrofula, and fistulas. 
 Tumor Bleeding and Inflammatio: For umbilical swelling and dampness, roast Lu Feng Fang to carbonize and grind to powder for external application. For tongue swelling with bleeding, mix 30g Lu Feng Fang, 12g Bei Mu (Fritillaria), and 9g Lu Hui (Aloe) into a powder, form pills with honey, and take 3g per dose with water. For bleeding nasal polyps, roast Lu Feng Fang to yellow, grind into powder, and take 6g per dose, three times daily with warm wine. For epistaxis (nosebleeds), the same roasted and powdered Lu Feng Fang is taken as above.
Contraindications: Use with caution in qi xu (qi deficiency) or xue xu (blood deficiency); contraindicated with gan jiang (dry ginger), dan shen (Salvia miltiorrhiza), huang qin (Scutellaria baicalensis), shao yao (peony), mu li (oyster shell). Not suitable for patients with conditions characterized primarily by qi and blood deficiency without external pathogens, or patients who are extremely deficient post-ulcer or abscess drainage due to depleted original qi.
Research: In vitro studies showed lu feng fang can inhibit human liver cancer cells and stomach cancer cells. Lu feng fang's alcohol, ether, and ketone extracts promote blood coagulation, enhance heart activity, temporarily lower blood pressure, and have a diuretic effect. Its oil (volatile oil) has strong expelling effect on tapeworms but is highly toxic and inappropriate for this purpose. High concentrations can inhibit frog heart and strongly stimulate kidneys causing acute nephritis.
